title: A Meta-Analysis of 46 Studies Identified by the FDA Demonstrates That Soy Protein Decreases Circulating LDL and Total Cholesterol Concentrations in Adults
study_type: Systematic review and meta-analysis of randomized trials
results_summary: This systematic review and meta-analysis of randomized trials evaluated soy protein in adults in nutrition intervention trials. Results showed that modest reductions in LDL cholesterol and total cholesterol versus control; mostly minor adverse events reported. Effects were generally modest and safety signals were acceptable, but larger and longer trials are recommended.
mla_citation: “A Meta-Analysis of 46 Studies Identified by the FDA Demonstrates That Soy Protein Decreases Circulating LDL and Total Cholesterol Concentrations in Adults.” PubMed, 2019, https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/31006811/. Accessed 24 Oct. 2025.

title: Extracted or synthesized soybean isoflavones reduce menopausal hot flash frequency and severity
results_summary: This meta-analysis of randomized trials evaluated soy isoflavones in perimenopausal and postmenopausal women. Results showed that reduced frequency and severity of hot flashes compared with placebo; mostly minor adverse events reported. Effects were generally modest and safety signals were acceptable, but larger and longer trials are recommended.
mla_citation: “Extracted or synthesized soybean isoflavones reduce menopausal hot flash frequency and severity.” PubMed, 2012, https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/22433977/. Accessed 24 Oct. 2025.

title: Effect of soy isoflavone extract supplements on bone mineral density in menopausal women: meta-analysis of randomized controlled trials
results_summary: This systematic review and meta-analysis evaluated soy isoflavone extract supplements in postmenopausal women in randomized trials. Results showed that modest increase in spinal bone mineral density over 6 to 12 months; mostly minor adverse events reported. Effects were generally modest and safety signals were acceptable, but larger and longer trials are recommended.
mla_citation: “Effect of soy isoflavone extract supplements on bone mineral density in menopausal women: meta-analysis of randomized controlled trials.” PubMed, 2010, https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/20199985/. Accessed 24 Oct. 2025.

title: The soy isoflavones for reducing bone loss (SIRBL) study: a 3-y randomized controlled trial in postmenopausal women
results_summary: This randomized double-blind trial evaluated soy isoflavone tablets in postmenopausal women. Results showed that no significant benefit on bone density or menopausal symptoms versus placebo; mostly minor adverse events reported. Effects were generally modest and safety signals were acceptable, but larger and longer trials are recommended.
mla_citation: “The soy isoflavones for reducing bone loss (SIRBL) study: a 3-y randomized controlled trial in postmenopausal women.” PubMed, 2010, https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/19906801/. Accessed 24 Oct. 2025.

title: Soy isoflavones in the prevention of menopausal bone loss and menopausal symptoms
results_summary: This randomized double-blind trial evaluated soy isoflavone tablets in women early in menopause. Results showed that no significant differences in bone loss or menopausal symptoms versus placebo; mostly minor adverse events reported. Effects were generally modest and safety signals were acceptable, but larger and longer trials are recommended.
mla_citation: “Soy isoflavones in the prevention of menopausal bone loss and menopausal symptoms.” PubMed, 2011, https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/21824950/. Accessed 24 Oct. 2025.

title: A North Central Cancer Treatment Group trial of soy for hot flashes
population: Women with a history of breast cancer experiencing hot flashes
results_summary: This randomized double-blind trial evaluated soy isoflavones in women with a history of breast cancer experiencing hot flashes. Results showed that no significant reduction in hot flashes versus placebo; mostly minor adverse events reported. Effects were generally modest and safety signals were acceptable, but larger and longer trials are recommended.
mla_citation: “A North Central Cancer Treatment Group trial of soy for hot flashes.” PubMed, 2000, https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/10694559/. Accessed 24 Oct. 2025.

title: Meta-analysis of the effects of soy protein intake on serum lipids
results_summary: This meta-analysis of randomized diet trials evaluated soy protein versus animal protein in adults in controlled diet studies. Results showed that reductions in total cholesterol, LDL cholesterol, and triglycerides with soy protein; mostly minor adverse events reported. Effects were generally modest and safety signals were acceptable, but larger and longer trials are recommended.
mla_citation: “Meta-analysis of the effects of soy protein intake on serum lipids.” PubMed, 1995, https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/7596371/. Accessed 24 Oct. 2025.

title: Various doses of soy isoflavones do not modify mammographic density in postmenopausal women
results_summary: This randomized double-blind trial evaluated soy isoflavone supplements in postmenopausal women. Results showed that no significant effect on mammographic density compared with placebo; mostly minor adverse events reported. Effects were generally modest and safety signals were acceptable, but larger and longer trials are recommended.
mla_citation: “Various doses of soy isoflavones do not modify mammographic density in postmenopausal women.” PubMed, 2009, https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/19321587/. Accessed 24 Oct. 2025.

title: Soy isoflavones: are they useful in menopause?
results_summary: This narrative review evaluated soy isoflavones in perimenopausal and postmenopausal women. Results showed that modest benefits for vasomotor symptoms with a favorable short-term safety profile; mostly minor adverse events reported. Effects were generally modest and safety signals were acceptable, but larger and longer trials are recommended.
mla_citation: “Soy isoflavones: are they useful in menopause?.” PubMed, 2000, https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/11075748/. Accessed 24 Oct. 2025.

title: Soy protein intake and blood pressure: meta-analysis of randomized controlled trials
results_summary: This meta-analysis of randomized controlled trials evaluated soy protein in adults with and without hypertension. Results showed that small reductions in systolic and diastolic blood pressure versus control; mostly minor adverse events reported. Effects were generally modest and safety signals were acceptable, but larger and longer trials are recommended.
mla_citation: “Soy protein intake and blood pressure: meta-analysis of randomized controlled trials.” PubMed, 2012, https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/22615484/. Accessed 24 Oct. 2025.
